DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures Little Changed in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade in thin trading typical of the holiday season. Slight losses in the wheat market reflected mild temperatures in the Great Plains, where winter wheat is grown. Light rain overnight in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer, put pressure on the soybean market while an increase in farmer selling kept a lid on gains in the corn futures. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 1\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.06 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $2.38} a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with March at $1.52{ a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to { cent higher with January at $5.64\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .13 cent lower to .08 cent higher with February at 77.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .30 cent lower with January at 84.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .13 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 49.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .35 cent to .50 cent higher with February at 49.65 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled lower on Wednesday while pork futures finished mixed.
